Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Deep Brain Stimulation vs. Levodopa on Autonomic Nervous System Functions in Parkinson's Disease

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 29 PD patients were enrolled.

Intervention.evidence: Fourteen patients underwent STN stimulation, and 15 received levodopa.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the impact of subthalamic nucleus (STN) deep brain stimulation on ANS functions compared to levodopa.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in cardiovascular ANS functions, assessed by blood pressure (BP) and heart rate (HR) during rest and orthostatic conditions, heart rate variability (HRV), and breathing-induced cutaneous sympathetic vasoconstriction (CVC).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the interventions, blinding was not feasible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 29 PD patients were enrolled.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis, with all participants included in the final analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: STN stimulation did not significantly alter cardiovascular ANS functions but significantly increased CVC. Conversely, levodopa significantly reduced BP and HR at rest and exacerbated orthostatic hypotension.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
